_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description

The AmeriGas Cullman terminal is propane storage and distribution facility. The facility includes six (6) above-ground storage tanks. Five of the tanks have a 30,000 gallons Water Capacity W.C each. One tank has a capacity of 19, 275 gallons W.C. There are three (3) Compressors used to unload the rails cars.  The terminal has a siding with six (6) rail towers designed to hook to rail cars and unload product to storage tanks using a system of Compressors. Compressors withdraw propane vapors from the storage tank and compress them or increase their pressure and discharge into the rail cars to be unloaded. This process slightly decreases the pressure in the bulk storage tanks and increases the pressure in the rail cars. As a result, liquid propane flows from rail car to the bulk storage tanks.

The terminal has two (2) Liquid Pumps and three (3) bulkheads. Using the loading pumps, transports are loaded at the terminal, when required.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy 

The same properties that make propane valuable as a fuel also make it necessary to practice certain safety precautions in handling it to prevent leaks, spills and accidents. First and foremost, in our operations, efforts are undertaken to ensure employee and contractor safety while on site as well as to minimize the risk of exposure to the surrounding communities. It is our company policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations. The Facility has a Regional Logistics Managers (RLMs) and a Terminal Operations Supervisor (TOS), who are able to immediately respond to a serious incident and provide technical expertise to emergency response agencies as needed at the scene of the incident. AmeriGas also maintains an around the clock Emergency Communications Center (ECC), which handles all after-hours and emergency calls from around the country.  The ECC has the ability to contact AmeriGas field personnel, as well as Chemtrec,

on any type of incident encountered at any AmeriGas location or by AmeriGas customers.



Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

Worst Case Scenario 

The worst case scenario that was considered was catastrophic release of propane from a 30, 000 Gallons Tank. Using EPA RMP Comp, the calculated worst case distance to 1 psi over pressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.4 miles

RMP Comp was used as a tool to calculate distance to endpoints of 1 psi over pressure. RMP Comp assumes meteorological conditions for the worst-case scenario of atmospheric stability class F (stable atmosphere) and wind speed 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour). Ambient air temperature assumed is 25? C (77? F). TNT-equivalent model is used which assumes a yield factor of 10 percent.



Alternative Release Scenario

For alternative release scenario, release from transfer hoses at the facility was considered. The active mitigation devices were assumed to work as designed, limiting the release to the contents of the hose. Using equation from Appendix C1 (EPA Offsite Consequence Analysis), the calculated distance to 1 psi over pressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.02 miles.



Emergency Response Plan

The facility maintains an Emergency Action Plan (EAP), which is designed to prepare employees during emergency situations.  The plan applies to emergencies that might be reasonably expected at the terminal. If an actual incident occurs, the plan gives guidance to employees on what actions to take. The plan identifies local fire department, hazmat response group with whom response efforts are coordinated.  The Plan is reviewed periodically to ensure that they remain up-to-date, reflecting current activities on site and employees are trained on their responsibilities in an emergency to ensure prompt response.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The facility has no plans at the present time to make any changes.
